main event: On November 7, 1957 in Dunedin, Florida, a round silvery object with a pulsing, flashing light was observed for seven or eight minutes, and it was concluded to be unidentified despite a hypothesis about the flashing light being caused by jet pulling non-persistent contrails.
interesting points: The sighting involved a round silvery object the size of a half dollar at arm's length, with a pulsing, flashing light approximately four times as long as the object.
The object remained stationary for seven or eight minutes, and it was estimated to be the size of a basketball.
A similar unidentified flying object was reported by separate military patrols near the spot where the first atomic bomb was exploded.
A bright object was observed near an A-bomb site in New Mexico, and specialists were called in to investigate the sighting.

The University of New Mexico's Department of Physics reported observing unusual flying saucers in Albuquerque, Roswell, and New Mexico, which were reported to be moving at a speed of 600 to 700 miles per hour with unusual maneuvering characteristics.
sighted object: round silvery object with a pulsing, flashing light
witnesses: military patrols, University of New Mexico's Department of Physics
